Award.AwardTitle: Genome-wide dynamics of neutral and fitness-related variation in a pedigreed population of Florida Scrub-Jays undergoing regional decline
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study examines genomic consequences of population decline within the endangered Florida Scrub-Jay, a bird species currently disappearing across its entire range. Capitalizing on a remarkable 43-year study of a locally protected population, DNA from 4,000+ individual jays sampled over 25 years will be characterized and compared using 9,000+ genetic markers. Ancestor-descendant pedigree, behavioral and structural characteristics, and lifetime reproductive performance for each individual are well documented. Combining field and whole-genome data for such a large sample of individuals over multiple generations is unprecedented for a wild animal population, providing exceptional opportunity to 1) measure how a contracting population changes genetically through time; 2) associate specific genes with individual variation in performance-related attributes; 3) identify areas of the genome responsible for reduced performance among inbred individuals; and 4) document how changes in immigration rate affect genetic structure of local populations. Overall, this longitudinal genomic characterization of a declining population promises to be the most detailed ever conducted in a free-living organism.

Besides being broadly informative for conservation genetics, this project is especially compelling because the Florida Scrub-Jay is a popular public symbol for biodiversity conservation amidst rapidly growing human populations. As local populations disappear, demand increases for information about the condition and viability of each population that remains. This study provides the means to measure genetic health of remnant populations, informs habitat protection priorities, and helps prescribe effective translocation strategies for genetic rescue of the most critically endangered populations. Students of all ages will gain experience in genetic methods, and outreach will occur at Archbold Biological Station and through Cornell Lab of Ornithology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Florida Scrub-Jay (FSJ) is a highly charismatic bird species that is entirely restricted to Florida, and is extremely popular among the general public. Explosive growth and impacts of the human population in Florida have drastically reduced the numbers of this jay, and now it is among the rarest bird species in North America. In order to understand the genetic implications of such extreme population fragmentation and loss, we (1) fully sequenced the FSJ genome; (2) developed and purified a library of 12,000 different genetic markers (SNPs); (3) used these markers to conduct a genome-wide analysis of over 4,000 individual FSJs from an archive of samples collected between 1987 and 2013, and whose complete life histories and pedigrees had been documented by a 45-year study of a large and well-protected population; (4) analyzed structural and life history features of our sample in relation to their genetic constitutions, including degree of inbreeding; (5) carefully tested the sample for evidence of natural selection either favoring or eliminating certain genetic types at different stages of the life cycle.

Our most immediately important result is that the study population experienced reduced rates of immigration from surrounding areas over our 25-year sampling period, and consequently is undergoing increasing levels of inbreeding and loss of genetic variability through time. Although the focal population remains large and numerically stable, nevertheless it is showing early signs of reduced individual fitness associated with lincreased inbreeding. Specifically, the level of genetic relatedness among members of a mated FSJ pair was an excellent predictor of the proportion of eggs in their nests failing to hatch. We also demonstrated that the extremely localized dispersal habits of FSJs result in significant genetic differences at the population level over remarkably short geographic distances. Finally, our genomic analyses also revealed specific areas of the genome that appear to be under active selection, and we are continuing to investigate whether any of these are of special importance to the survival of FSJs under conditions of reduced population size and elevated inbreeding.

Our results are already being used to reshape the official conservation plans and priorities for recovering this endangered species. Most important, the FSJ recovery team has acknowledged our conclusion that certain small and seemingly trivial populations can play a crucial role in population persistence and recovery. Such populations can be sources of vital genetic variation for larger, seemingly stable core populations, even as these smaller ones themselves lose their own genetic variation.

Our study is pioneering in several ways. First, conducting detailed genomic analyses in a population for which every individual has a known lifetime history is almost unheard of, because assembling the background data demands enormous investments of time, energy, genetic sampling, and meticulous record-keeping over many decades. Second, our study began a long-term and ongoing “deep dive" into the genomic implications of population decline in a very high-profile endangered species. By applying next-generation genomic technology to understanding how population fragmentation affects population genetics, we will use this information to help guide protection and recovery of this and other endangered species. Third, our study is yielding one of the most complete genomes and maps of genetic linkage for any bird, and these genetic resources will be useful for countless additional studies of avian evolution, natural selection, and the genetic sources of variation in survival and reproductive success (i.e., "fitness") among wild birds.
